tit.cmt: タイトルのため、括弧内の補足を削除しました。

sen.j: 麩（ふ）は、グルテンを主原料とした加工食品。
sen.e: Wheat gluten cakes are processed food made with wheat gluten being the main ingredient.
Wheat gluten cakes are a processed food made with wheat gluten being the main ingredient.
"Fu" refers to a processed food made with wheat gluten being the main ingredient.

sen.j: グルテンは、水で練った小麦粉に含まれるたんぱく質のひとつである。
sen.e: Gluten is a type of protein contained in the water and wheat flour mixture.

sen.j: モチモチした食感をもつ生麩（なまふ）と、サクサクカリカリした食感の焼き麩（やきふ）、中華料理などで使われる揚げ麩（あげふ）がある。
sen.e: Wheat gluten cakes are available in various forms including the chewy nama-fu (fresh gluten cakes), the crisp yaki-fu (toasted gluten cakes) and age-fu (deep-fat fried gluten cakes) used in Chinese cooking.

sen.j: 精進料理（日本・中国）、もしくは欧米では健康または宗教上の理由で肉類を食べない菜食主義者向けの、肉を模した代用食品の原料として麩が使われる。

sen.j: 小麦粉に食塩水を加えてよく練って生地を作る。
sen.e: Add brine to flour and knead the mixture to make dough.
Add brine to flour and knead the mixture to make dough.

sen.j: 粘りが出たところで生地を布製の袋に入れる。
sen.e: When the dough becomes sticky, transfer it in a cloth bag.
When the dough becomes sticky, transfer it to a cloth bag.
When the dough becomes sticky, transfer it to a cloth bag.

sen.j: 生地を水中で更に揉む。
sen.e: Submerge the cloth bag in water and continue kneading the dough.

sen.j: デンプンが流出した後に残ったグルテンを蒸して生麩（もち麩）が作られる。
sen.e: When starch in the dough has flowed out in water, gluten remaining is steamed to make fresh gluten cake (or mochi-fu).
When starch in the dough has flowed out into the water, the remaining gluten is steamed to make fresh gluten cake (or mochi-fu).
When starch in the dough has flowed out into the water, the remaining gluten is steamed to make nama-fu (or mochi-fu).

sen.e: Knead together the above gluten, wheat flour, baking powder and glutinous rice flour and toast this dough to make toasted gluten cakes.

sen.j: 中国では古くは麪筋（めんきん）と呼ばれ、宋 (王朝)に書かれた『夢渓筆談』にもその名が登場する。
sen.e: In old China, fu was referred to as mian jin (gluten) and was mentioned in "Meng Xi Bi Tan" (Dream Stream Essays) which was written during the Sung Dynasty era.

sen.j: 日本では「麩」という字で糠（ふすま）を指し、後にその加工品である麪筋にもこの字が当てられた（『本朝食鑑』）。
sen.e: In Japan, the kanji representing 'fu' means rice bran and that character was used for mian jin (gluten) which is a processed food made from rice bran later on.
In Japan, the kanji representing 'fu' means rice bran and that character was used for mian jin (gluten) which is a processed food made from rice bran later on.

In Japan, the kanji representing 'fu' means rice bran and that character was used for mian jin which is a processed food made from rice bran later on ("Honcho shokkan" [Mirror of food in our country])
sen.cmt: 『本朝食鑑』 と補足を追加しました。

sen.j: また、小麦そのものが中国大陸から伝来されたことから唐粉（からこ、殻粉）とも称した。
sen.e: Additionally, since wheat came from China, it was also referred to as Chinese flour.
Additionally, since wheat came from China, it was also referred to as Chinese flour.
Additionally, since wheat came from China, it was also referred to as Karako (Chinese flour).
sen.cmt: 唐粉 を追加しました。

sen.j: 鎌倉時代には唐粉を宮廷に貢納する供御人（唐粉供御人）がいた。
sen.e: During the Kamakura Period, there were Kugonin (purveyors to the imperial household) who paid a tribute of Chinese flour to the Imperial household.
During the Kamakura Period, there were Kugonin (purveyors to the imperial household) who paid a tribute of Chinese flour to the Imperial household.
During the Kamakura period, there were Kugonin (Karako kugonin) who paid a tribute of Karako to the Imperial household.
sen.cmt: 唐粉供御人 を追加しました。

sen.j: 「麩＝ふ」としての最古の記録は南北朝時代 (日本)に書かれた『嘉元記』正平 (日本)7年（1352年）5月10日条に登場する「フ」の記述である（なお、同条に「フ」と併記されている「ウトム」がうどんの最古の記録とされている）。
sen.e: The oldest documented record on 'fu' is the description of 'fu'in the article, dated May 10, 1352, in"Kagenki" which was written during the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (and it is said that 'utomu' which was mentioned along with 'fu' in that article is the oldest documented record on udon (Japanese wheat noodles)).

The oldest documented record on 'fu' is the description of 'fu' in the article dated May 10, 1352, in"Kagenki" which was written during the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (and it is said that 'utomu' which was mentioned along with 'fu' in that article is the oldest documented record on udon - Japanese wheat noodles).

The oldest documented record on 'fu' is the description of 'fu' in the article dated June 30, 1352, in "Kagenki" which was written during the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan) (and it is said that 'utomu' which was mentioned along with 'fu' in that article is the oldest documented record on udon - Japanese wheat noodles).
sen.cmt: クォーテーションマークの種類を変更しました。グレゴリオ暦に変更しました。

sen.j: 禅宗の広まりとともに精進料理や懐石料理などで麩が採用され、日本の食卓でも馴染みのものになっていった。
sen.e: As the Zen sect gained its popularity, fu began to be used in the Buddhist cuisine and kaiseki ryori (a simple meal served before a ceremonial tea) becoming a common food item on dining tables in Japan.
As the Zen sect gained popularity, fu began to be used in the Buddhist cuisine and kaiseki ryori (a simple meal served before a ceremonial tea), becoming a common food item on dining tables in Japan.
As the Zen sect gained popularity, fu began to be used in the Buddhist cuisine and kaiseki ryori (a simple meal served before a ceremonial tea), becoming a common food item on dining tables in Japan.
